alert.note: Alert for Pickens (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 04 at 11:07AM EDT until September 04 at 3:30PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 215 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, Oconee and Pickens. * WHEN...Until 215 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1104 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rainfall due to repeated showers and embedded thunderstorms. This will cause small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen over the past 3 hours and an additional inch is possible through 1 pm. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Seneca, Walhalla, Salem, Lake Keowee, Devils Fork State Park, Lake Jocassee, Lake Hartwell and Townville. Flooding is most likely along Seneca Creek and tributaries to Lake Hartwell and Lake Keowee. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
